title-group.article-title: Design of Aerodynamic Diagonal Flow Fan for Engine Cooling

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1999 Society of Automotive Engineers, Inc.

abstract.p: Automobile cooling system fans have predominantly been axial fans, due to their low cost, thinness, and ease of mounting. However, since flow resistances in front and back of the fan are very strong, air tends to flow diagonally at the fan outlet side. The fan does not operate as an axial flow fan. In order to move towards the operation of an axial flow fan as a diagonal flow fan, this report introduces the idea of the diagonal flow design with an "aerodynamic diagonal flow hub". In order to give this idea as broad an application as possible, we generalized from an obser-vation of the relation between design flow coefficient and operating range, and engaged in experimental studies, design, and prototype manufacture. In the end, we verified that the new design features have higher performance and lower noise than the ordinary axial flow fan.

ref.mixed-citation: T. Ikui M.lnoue: Turbo-Blowers and Compressors, P.480- 487, Corona Pub. Co., (1988)
B. R. Baranski: Design the Engine Cooling Fan, SAE Paper, 740691, (1974)
H. Katagiri K. Fujikake K. Yamada: Automotive Mixed Flow Fan with Guide Vanes on Blade Surfaces, SAE Paper, 800034, (1980)
T. Mizuno K. Kikuchi: Characteristics of Axial Flow Fan with Diagonal Flow Hub, SAE Paper, 900085, (1990)
K. Shimada T. Kuriwada N. Ishii K. Ohyama: Aerodynamic Design of Mixed Flow Fan which has the structure of Axial Fan, The 72th JASME Spring Annual Meeting, 95-1, (1 995)
L. J. Herrig J. C. Emery J. R. Erwin: Systematic Two- Dimensional Cascade Tests of NACA 65-Series Compres- sor Blades at Low Speeds, NACA Technical Note, 3916, (1957)
M. Inoue: Experimental Study on the Two-Dimentional Retarded Cascade, Memoirs of the Faculty of Engineering Kyushu University, Vol. 31, No.3, (1 972)
